newsitem.title: USA: Cronkite admitted for heart bypass surgery.
newsitem.headline: Cronkite admitted for heart bypass surgery.

text.p: Walter Cronkite, the CBS anchorman who set the tone for the dominance of network television news, was admitted to a hospital on Tuesday for heart surgery, his assistant said.
"He is in the hospital for quadruple bypass surgery," Julie Sukman, Cronkite's assistant at CBS, said. "He did not have a heart attack, the surgery was recommended after a check up last week."
The New York Hospital Cornell Medical Centre confirmed that Cronkite, 80, had been admitted to the Manhattan hospital but declined to give further details.

Cronkite started the first national half-hour nightly news for CBS in September 1963 and presided over it until he retired at age 65 in 1981, developing a reputation as the "most trusted man in America."

In his memoir, "A Reporter's Life", published at the end of last year, Cronkite wrote that the medium he helped create -- it weaned many Americans off newspapers and led them to depend first on TV for news -- was seriously flawed and that his greatest disappointment was not going to the moon.
